definition.name: Charlatan
definition.description:
Ability Scores: Dexterity, Constitution, Charisma
Feat: Skilled
Skill Proficiencies: Deception and Sleight of Hand
Tool Proficiency: Forgery Kit
Equipment: Choose A or B: (A) Forgery Kit, Costume, Fine Clothes, 15 GP; or (B) 50 GP

Once you were old enough to order an ale, you soon had a favorite stool in every tavern within ten miles of where you were born. As you traveled the circuit from public house to watering hole, you learned to prey on unfortunates who were in the market for a comforting lie or two—perhaps a sham potion or forged ancestry records.
definition.shortDescription: Once you were old enough to order an ale, you soon had a favorite stool in every tavern within ten miles of where you were born. As you traveled the circuit from public house to watering hole, you learned to prey on unfortunates who were in the market for a comforting lie or two—perhaps a sham potion or forged ancestry records.
definition.equipmentDescription: Choose A or B: (A) Forgery Kit, Costume, Fine Clothes, 15 GP; or (B) 50 GP

race.description:
Halflings possess a brave and adventurous spirit that leads them on journeys of discovery.

Halfling Traits
Brave, Halfling Nimbleness, Luck, Naturally Stealthy

definition.name: Brave
definition.description: You have Advantage on saving throws you make to avoid or end the Frightened condition.
definition.snippet: You have Advantage on saving throws you make to avoid or end the Frightened condition.

definition.name: Halfling Nimbleness
definition.description: You can move through the space of any creature that is a size larger than you, but you can’t stop in the same space.
definition.snippet: You can move through the space of any creature that is a size larger than you, but you can’t stop in the same space.

definition.name: Luck
definition.description: When you roll a 1 on the d20 of a D20 Test, you can reroll the die, and you must use the new roll.
definition.snippet: When you roll a 1 on the d20 of a D20 Test, you can reroll the die, and you must use the new roll.

definition.name: Naturally Stealthy
definition.description: You can take the Hide action even when you are obscured only by a creature that is at least one size larger than you.
definition.snippet: You can take the Hide action even when you are obscured only by a creature that is at least one size larger than you.

definition.name: Creature Type
definition.description: You are Humanoid.
definition.snippet: You are Humanoid.

definition.name: Size
definition.description: Your Size is Small (about 2–3 feet tall).
definition.snippet: Your Size is Small.

definition.name: Speed
definition.description: Your Speed is 30 feet.
definition.snippet: Your Speed is 30 ft.

definition.name: Ability Score Increases
definition.description: When determining your character’s ability scores, increase one score by 2 and a different one by 1, or increase three scores by 1. None of these increases can raise a score above 20.
definition.snippet: When determining your character’s ability scores, increase one score by 2 and a different one by 1, or increase three scores by 1.

definition.name: Languages
definition.description:
Your character knows at least three languages: Common plus two languages you roll or choose from the Standard Languages table. Knowledge of a language means your character can communicate in it, read it, and write it. Your class and other features might also give you languages.

The Standard Languages table lists languages that are widespread on D&D worlds. Every player character knows Common, which originated in the planar metropolis of Sigil, the hub of the multiverse. The other standard languages originated with the first members of the most prominent species in the worlds of D&D and have since spread widely.

Standard Languages
1d12 Language Origin
— Common Sigil
1 Common Sign Language Sigil
2 Draconic Dragons
3-4 Dwarvish Dwarves
5-6 Elvish Elves
7 Giant Giants
8 Gnomish Gnomish
9 Goblin Goblinoids
10-11 Halfling Halflings
12 Orc Orcs
definition.snippet: Your character knows at least three languages: Common plus two languages you roll or choose from the Standard Languages table. Knowledge of a language means your character can communicate in it, read it, and write it.

notes.backstory:
Starting from a young age Remix would get in all kinds of mischief and trouble, sneaking into places he shouldn't, stealing odd things, or just making a ruckus. Before he was even old enough, he found the taverns and watering holes, frequenting any he could find. While there he picked up on the music from a bard and decided to start an apprentice ship. 

After finally coming into his own as a bard, Remix sets out to seek new adventures, hopping from tavern to tavern or any gathering where drinks are sold, still causing mischief here and there

definition.name: Leather
definition.description: The breastplate and shoulder protectors of this armor are made of leather that has been stiffened by being boiled in oil. The rest of the armor is made of softer and more flexible materials.

definition.name: Dagger
definition.description:
Proficiency with a Dagger allows you to add your proficiency bonus to the attack roll for any attack you make with it.

This weapon has the following mastery property. To use this property, you must have a feature that lets you use it.

Nick. When you make the extra attack of the Light property, you can make it as part of the Attack action instead of as a Bonus Action. You can make this extra attack only once per turn.

properties.name: Finesse
properties.description: When making an attack with a finesse weapon, you use your choice of your Strength or Dexterity modifier for the attack and damage rolls. You must use the same modifier for both rolls.

properties.name: Light
properties.description: A light weapon is small and easy to handle, making it ideal for use when fighting with two weapons.

properties.name: Thrown
properties.description: If a weapon has the thrown property, you can throw the weapon to make a ranged attack. If the weapon is a melee weapon, you use the same ability modifier for that attack roll and damage roll that you would use for a melee attack with the weapon. For example, if you throw a handaxe, you use your Strength, but if you throw a dagger, you can use either your Strength or your Dexterity, since the dagger has the finesse property.

properties.name: Nick
properties.description: When you make the extra attack of the [wprop]Light[/wprop] property, you can make it as part of the [action]Attack[/action] action instead of as a Bonus Action. You can make this extra attack only once per turn.

definition.name: Dagger
definition.description:
Proficiency with a Dagger allows you to add your proficiency bonus to the attack roll for any attack you make with it.

This weapon has the following mastery property. To use this property, you must have a feature that lets you use it.

Nick. When you make the extra attack of the Light property, you can make it as part of the Attack action instead of as a Bonus Action. You can make this extra attack only once per turn.

properties.name: Finesse
properties.description: When making an attack with a finesse weapon, you use your choice of your Strength or Dexterity modifier for the attack and damage rolls. You must use the same modifier for both rolls.

properties.name: Light
properties.description: A light weapon is small and easy to handle, making it ideal for use when fighting with two weapons.

properties.name: Thrown
properties.description: If a weapon has the thrown property, you can throw the weapon to make a ranged attack. If the weapon is a melee weapon, you use the same ability modifier for that attack roll and damage roll that you would use for a melee attack with the weapon. For example, if you throw a handaxe, you use your Strength, but if you throw a dagger, you can use either your Strength or your Dexterity, since the dagger has the finesse property.

properties.name: Nick
properties.description: When you make the extra attack of the [wprop]Light[/wprop] property, you can make it as part of the [action]Attack[/action] action instead of as a Bonus Action. You can make this extra attack only once per turn.

definition.name: Backpack
definition.description: A Backpack holds up to 30 pounds within 1 cubic foot. It can also serve as a saddlebag.

definition.name: Bagpipes
definition.description:
Ability: Charisma
Utilize: Play a known tune (DC 10), or improvise a song (DC 15)

definition.name: Lyre
definition.description:
Ability: Charisma
Utilize: Play a known tune (DC 10), or improvise a song (DC 15)

definition.name: Pan Flute
definition.description:
Ability: Charisma
Utilize: Play a known tune (DC 10), or improvise a song (DC 15)

definition.name: Oil
definition.description:
You can douse a creature, object, or space with Oil or use it as fuel, as detailed below.

Dousing a Creature or an Object. When you take the Attack action, you can replace one of your attacks with throwing an Oil flask. Target one creature or object within 20 feet of yourself. The target must succeed on a Dexterity saving throw (DC 8 plus your Dexterity modifier and Proficiency Bonus) or be covered in oil. If the target takes Fire damage before the oil dries (after 1 minute), the target takes an extra 5 Fire damage from burning oil.

Dousing a Space. You can take the Utilize action to pour an Oil flask on level ground to cover a 5-foot-square area within 5 feet of yourself. If lit, the oil burns until the end of the turn 2 rounds from when the oil was lit (or 12 seconds) and deals 5 Fire damage to any creature that enters the area or ends its turn there. A creature can take this damage only once per turn.

Fuel. Oil serves as fuel for Lamps and Lanterns. Once lit, a flask of Oil burns for 6 hours in a Lamp or Lantern. That duration doesn’t need to be consecutive; you can extinguish the burning Oil (as a Utilize action) and rekindle it again until it has burned for a total of 6 hours.

definition.name: Rations
definition.description: Rations consist of travel-ready food, including jerky, dried fruit, hardtack, and nuts. See “Malnutrition” for the risks of not eating.

definition.name: Bedroll
definition.description: A Bedroll sleeps one Small or Medium creature. While in a Bedroll, you automatically succeed on saving throws against extreme cold (see the Dungeon Master’s Guide).

definition.name: Bell
definition.description: When rung as a Utilize action, a Bell produces a sound that can be heard up to 60 feet away.

definition.name: Tinderbox
definition.description: A Tinderbox is a small container holding flint, fire steel, and tinder (usually dry cloth soaked in light oil) used to kindle a fire. Using it to light a Candle, Lamp, Lantern, or Torch—or anything else with exposed fuel—takes a Bonus Action. Lighting any other fire takes 1 minute.

definition.name: Waterskin
definition.description: A Waterskin holds up to 4 pints. If you don’t drink sufficient water, you risk dehydration.

definition.name: Mirror
definition.description: A handheld steel Mirror is useful for personal cosmetics but also for peeking around corners and reflecting light as a signal.

definition.name: Bullseye Lantern
definition.description: A Bullseye Lantern burns Oil as fuel to cast Bright Light in a 60-foot Cone and Dim Light for an additional 60 feet.

definition.name: Costume
definition.description: While wearing a Costume, you have Advantage on any ability check you make to impersonate the person or type of person it represents.

definition.name: Bard
definition.description:
An Inspiring Performer of Music, Dance, and Magic

Bards are expert at inspiring others, soothing hurts, disheartening foes, and creating illusions.

Primary Ability: Charisma
Hit Point Die: D8
Saves: Dexterity & Charisma
definition.equipmentDescription:
Choose A or B:
(A) Leather Armor, 2 Daggers, Musical Instrument of your choice, Entertainer’s Pack, and 19 GP; or
(B) 90 GP

classFeatures.name: Bardic Inspiration
classFeatures.description:
You can supernaturally inspire others through words, music, or dance. This inspiration is represented by your Bardic Inspiration die, which is a d6.

Using Bardic Inspiration. As a Bonus Action, you can inspire another creature within 60 feet of yourself who can see or hear you. That creature gains one of your Bardic Inspiration dice. A creature can have only one Bardic Inspiration die at a time.

Once within the next hour when the creature fails a D20 Test, the creature can roll the Bardic Inspiration die and add the number rolled to the d20, potentially turning the failure into a success. A Bardic Inspiration die is expended when it’s rolled.

Number of Uses. You can confer a Bardic Inspiration die a number of times equal to your Charisma modifier (minimum of once), and you regain all expended uses when you finish a Long Rest.

At Higher Levels. Your Bardic Inspiration die changes when you reach certain Bard levels, as shown in the Bardic Die column of the Bard Features table. The die becomes a d8 at level 5, a d10 at level 10, and a d12 at level 15.

classFeatures.name: Core Bard Traits
classFeatures.description:
As a Level 1 Character you gain:

  • Gain all the traits in the Core Bard Traits table.
  • Gain the Bard’s level 1 features.
Core Bard Traits
Primary Ability Charisma
Hit Point Die D8 per Bard level
Saving Throw Proficiencies Dexterity and Charisma
Skill Proficiencies Choose any 3 skills (see chapter 1 of the Player’s Handbook)
Weapon Proficiencies Simple weapons
Tool Proficiencies Choose 3 Musical Instruments (see chapter 6 of the Player’s Handbook)
Armor Training Light armor
Starting Equipment Choose A or B: (A) Leather Armor, 2 Daggers, Musical Instrument of your choice, Entertainer’s Pack, and 19 GP; or (B) 90 GP

classFeatures.name: Spellcasting
classFeatures.description:
You have learned to cast spells through your bardic arts.

Cantrips. You know two cantrips of your choice from the Bard spell list.

Whenever you gain a Bard level, you can replace one of your cantrips with another cantrip of your choice from the Bard spell list.

When you reach Bard levels 4 and 10, you learn another cantrip of your choice from the Bard spell list, as shown in the Cantrips column of the Bard Features table.

Spell Slots. The Bard Features table shows how many spell slots you have to cast your level 1+ spells. You regain all expended slots when you finish a Long Rest.

Prepared Spells of Level 1+. You prepare the list of level 1+ spells that are available for you to cast with this feature. To start, choose four level 1 spells from the Bard spell list.

The number of spells on your list increases as you gain Bard levels, as shown in the Prepared Spells column of the Bard Features table. Whenever that number increases, choose additional spells from the Bard spell list until the number of spells on your list matches the number on the table. The chosen spells must be of a level for which you have spell slots. For example, if you’re a level 3 Bard, your list of prepared spells can include six spells of levels 1 and 2 in any combination.

If another Bard feature gives you spells that you always have prepared, those spells don’t count against the number of spells you can prepare with this feature, but those spells otherwise count as Bard spells for you.

Changing Your Prepared Spells. Whenever you gain a Bard level, you can replace one spell on your list with another Bard spell for which you have spell slots.

Spellcasting Ability. Charisma is your spellcasting ability for your Bard spells.

Spellcasting Focus. You can use a Musical Instrument as a Spellcasting Focus for your Bard spells.

classFeatures.name: Expertise
classFeatures.description:
You gain Expertise in two of your skill proficiencies of your choice.

At Bard level 9, you gain Expertise in two more of your skill proficiencies of your choice.

classFeatures.name: Jack of All Trades
classFeatures.description:
You can add half your Proficiency Bonus (round down) to any ability check you make that uses a skill proficiency you lack and that doesn’t otherwise use your Proficiency Bonus.

For example, if you make a Strength (Athletics) check and lack Athletics proficiency, you can add half your Proficiency Bonus to the check.

classFeatures.name: Bard Subclass
classFeatures.description: You gain a Bard subclass of your choice. A subclass is a specialization that grants you features at certain Bard levels. For the rest of your career, you gain each of your subclass’s features that are of your Bard level or lower.

classFeatures.name: Ability Score Improvement
classFeatures.description: You gain the Ability Score Improvement feat or another feat of your choice for which you qualify. You gain this feature again at Bard levels 8, 12, and 16.

classFeatures.name: Font of Inspiration
classFeatures.description:
You now regain all your expended uses of Bardic Inspiration when you finish a Short or Long Rest.

In addition, you can expend a spell slot (no action required) to regain one expended use of Bardic Inspiration.

classFeatures.name: Countercharm
classFeatures.description: You can use musical notes or words of power to disrupt mind-influencing effects. If you or a creature within 30 feet of you fails a saving throw against an effect that applies the Charmed or Frightened condition, you can take a Reaction to cause the save to be rerolled, and the new roll has Advantage.

classFeatures.name: 8: Ability Score Increase
classFeatures.description: You gain the Ability Score Improvement feat or another feat of your choice for which you qualify. You gain this feature again at Bard levels 12 and 16.

classFeatures.name: Magical Secrets
classFeatures.description: You’ve learned secrets from various magical traditions. Whenever you reach a Bard level (including this level) and the Prepared Spells number in the Bard Features table increases, you can choose any of your new prepared spells from the Bard, Cleric, Druid, and Wizard spell lists, and the chosen spells count as Bard spells for you. In addition, whenever you replace a spell prepared for this class, you can replace it with a spell from those lists.

classFeatures.name: 12: Ability Score Improvement
classFeatures.description: You gain the Ability Score Improvement feat or another feat of your choice for which you qualify. You gain this feature again at Bard level 16.

classFeatures.name: 16: Ability Score Improvement
classFeatures.description: You gain the Ability Score Improvement feat or another feat of your choice for which you qualify.

classFeatures.name: Superior Inspiration
classFeatures.description: When you roll Initiative, you regain expended uses of Bardic Inspiration until you have two if you have fewer than that.

classFeatures.name: Epic Boon
classFeatures.description: You gain an Epic Boon feat or another feat of your choice for which you qualify.

classFeatures.name: Words of Creation
classFeatures.description: You have mastered two of the Words of Creation: the words of life and death. You therefore always have the Power Word Heal and Power Word Kill spells prepared. When you cast either spell, you can target a second creature with it if that creature is within 10 feet of the first target.

classFeatures.name: Bardic Inspiration
classFeatures.description:
You can supernaturally inspire others through words, music, or dance. This inspiration is represented by your Bardic Inspiration die, which is a d6.

Using Bardic Inspiration. As a Bonus Action, you can inspire another creature within 60 feet of yourself who can see or hear you. That creature gains one of your Bardic Inspiration dice. A creature can have only one Bardic Inspiration die at a time.

Once within the next hour when the creature fails a D20 Test, the creature can roll the Bardic Inspiration die and add the number rolled to the d20, potentially turning the failure into a success. A Bardic Inspiration die is expended when it’s rolled.

Number of Uses. You can confer a Bardic Inspiration die a number of times equal to your Charisma modifier (minimum of once), and you regain all expended uses when you finish a Long Rest.

At Higher Levels. Your Bardic Inspiration die changes when you reach certain Bard levels, as shown in the Bardic Die column of the Bard Features table. The die becomes a d8 at level 5, a d10 at level 10, and a d12 at level 15.

classFeatures.name: 9: Expertise
classFeatures.description: You gain Expertise in two more of your skill proficiencies of your choice.

definition.name: Bardic Inspiration
definition.description:
You can supernaturally inspire others through words, music, or dance. This inspiration is represented by your Bardic Inspiration die, which is a d6.

Using Bardic Inspiration. As a Bonus Action, you can inspire another creature within 60 feet of yourself who can see or hear you. That creature gains one of your Bardic Inspiration dice. A creature can have only one Bardic Inspiration die at a time.

Once within the next hour when the creature fails a D20 Test, the creature can roll the Bardic Inspiration die and add the number rolled to the d20, potentially turning the failure into a success. A Bardic Inspiration die is expended when it’s rolled.

Number of Uses. You can confer a Bardic Inspiration die a number of times equal to your Charisma modifier (minimum of once), and you regain all expended uses when you finish a Long Rest.

At Higher Levels. Your Bardic Inspiration die changes when you reach certain Bard levels, as shown in the Bardic Die column of the Bard Features table. The die becomes a d8 at level 5, a d10 at level 10, and a d12 at level 15.
definition.snippet:
As a Bonus Action, you can inspire another creature within 60 ft. that can see or hear you. That creature gains one of your Bardic Inspiration dice ({{scalevalue}}). Once within the next hour, when the creature fails a D20 Test, the creature can roll the Bardic Inspiration die and add the number rolled to the total, potentially turning the failure into a success.

You can confer your Bardic Inspiration die {{modifier:cha@min:1#unsigned}} times per Long Rest.

definition.name: Core Bard Traits
definition.description:
As a Level 1 Character you gain:

  • Gain all the traits in the Core Bard Traits table.
  • Gain the Bard’s level 1 features.
Core Bard Traits
Primary Ability Charisma
Hit Point Die D8 per Bard level
Saving Throw Proficiencies Dexterity and Charisma
Skill Proficiencies Choose any 3 skills (see chapter 1 of the Player’s Handbook)
Weapon Proficiencies Simple weapons
Tool Proficiencies Choose 3 Musical Instruments (see chapter 6 of the Player’s Handbook)
Armor Training Light armor
Starting Equipment Choose A or B: (A) Leather Armor, 2 Daggers, Musical Instrument of your choice, Entertainer’s Pack, and 19 GP; or (B) 90 GP
definition.multiClassDescription:
As a Multiclass Character:

  • Gain the following traits from the Core Bard Traits table: Hit Point Die, proficiency in one skill of your choice, proficiency with one Musical Instrument of your choice, and training with Light armor.
  • Gain the Bard’s level 1 features.
Core Bard Traits
Primary Ability Charisma
Hit Point Die D8 per Bard level
Skill Proficiencies Choose any 1 skill
Tool Proficiencies Choose 1 Musical Instruments
Armor Training Light armor

definition.name: Spellcasting
definition.description:
You have learned to cast spells through your bardic arts.

Cantrips. You know two cantrips of your choice from the Bard spell list.

Whenever you gain a Bard level, you can replace one of your cantrips with another cantrip of your choice from the Bard spell list.

When you reach Bard levels 4 and 10, you learn another cantrip of your choice from the Bard spell list, as shown in the Cantrips column of the Bard Features table.

Spell Slots. The Bard Features table shows how many spell slots you have to cast your level 1+ spells. You regain all expended slots when you finish a Long Rest.

Prepared Spells of Level 1+. You prepare the list of level 1+ spells that are available for you to cast with this feature. To start, choose four level 1 spells from the Bard spell list.

The number of spells on your list increases as you gain Bard levels, as shown in the Prepared Spells column of the Bard Features table. Whenever that number increases, choose additional spells from the Bard spell list until the number of spells on your list matches the number on the table. The chosen spells must be of a level for which you have spell slots. For example, if you’re a level 3 Bard, your list of prepared spells can include six spells of levels 1 and 2 in any combination.

If another Bard feature gives you spells that you always have prepared, those spells don’t count against the number of spells you can prepare with this feature, but those spells otherwise count as Bard spells for you.

Changing Your Prepared Spells. Whenever you gain a Bard level, you can replace one spell on your list with another Bard spell for which you have spell slots.

Spellcasting Ability. Charisma is your spellcasting ability for your Bard spells.

Spellcasting Focus. You can use a Musical Instrument as a Spellcasting Focus for your Bard spells.
definition.snippet: You can spells through your bardic arts. Charisma is your spellcasting ability for your Bard spells (Spell DC {{savedc:cha}}, Spell Attack {{spellattack:cha}}). You can use a Musical Instrument as a Spellcasting Focus for your Bard spells.

definition.name: Expertise
definition.description:
You gain Expertise in two of your skill proficiencies of your choice.

At Bard level 9, you gain Expertise in two more of your skill proficiencies of your choice.
definition.snippet: You gain Expertise in two skill proficiencies of your choice.

definition.name: Jack of All Trades
definition.description:
You can add half your Proficiency Bonus (round down) to any ability check you make that uses a skill proficiency you lack and that doesn’t otherwise use your Proficiency Bonus.

For example, if you make a Strength (Athletics) check and lack Athletics proficiency, you can add half your Proficiency Bonus to the check.
definition.snippet: You can add half your Proficiency Bonus ({{(proficiency/2)@rounddown}}) ability checks you make that uses a skill proficiency you lack and that doesn’t otherwise use your Proficiency Bonus.

definition.name: Bard Subclass
definition.description: You gain a Bard subclass of your choice. A subclass is a specialization that grants you features at certain Bard levels. For the rest of your career, you gain each of your subclass’s features that are of your Bard level or lower.

definition.name: Ability Score Improvement
definition.description: You gain the Ability Score Improvement feat or another feat of your choice for which you qualify. You gain this feature again at Bard levels 8, 12, and 16.

definition.name: Font of Inspiration
definition.description:
You now regain all your expended uses of Bardic Inspiration when you finish a Short or Long Rest.

In addition, you can expend a spell slot (no action required) to regain one expended use of Bardic Inspiration.
definition.snippet:
You now regain all expended uses of Bardic Inspiration when you finish a Short or Long Rest.

In addition, you can expend a spell slot (no action required) to regain one expended use of Bardic Inspiration.

definition.name: Countercharm
definition.description: You can use musical notes or words of power to disrupt mind-influencing effects. If you or a creature within 30 feet of you fails a saving throw against an effect that applies the Charmed or Frightened condition, you can take a Reaction to cause the save to be rerolled, and the new roll has Advantage.
definition.snippet: If you or a creature within 30 ft. fails a saving throw against an effect that applies the Charmed or Frightened condition, you can take a Reaction to cause the save to be rerolled with Advantage.

definition.name: 8: Ability Score Increase
definition.description: You gain the Ability Score Improvement feat or another feat of your choice for which you qualify. You gain this feature again at Bard levels 12 and 16.

definition.name: Magical Secrets
definition.description: You’ve learned secrets from various magical traditions. Whenever you reach a Bard level (including this level) and the Prepared Spells number in the Bard Features table increases, you can choose any of your new prepared spells from the Bard, Cleric, Druid, and Wizard spell lists, and the chosen spells count as Bard spells for you. In addition, whenever you replace a spell prepared for this class, you can replace it with a spell from those lists.
definition.snippet: Whenever you reach a Bard level that increases the number of Prepared Spells you have, you can choose any of your new prepared spells from the Bard, Cleric, Druid, and Wizard spell lists, and they count as Bard spells for you. In addition, whenever you replace a spell prepared for this class, you can replace it with a spell from those lists.

definition.name: 12: Ability Score Improvement
definition.description: You gain the Ability Score Improvement feat or another feat of your choice for which you qualify. You gain this feature again at Bard level 16.

definition.name: 16: Ability Score Improvement
definition.description: You gain the Ability Score Improvement feat or another feat of your choice for which you qualify.

definition.name: Superior Inspiration
definition.description: When you roll Initiative, you regain expended uses of Bardic Inspiration until you have two if you have fewer than that.
definition.snippet: When you roll Initiative, you regain expended uses of Bardic Inspiration until you have 2 if you have fewer than that.

definition.name: Epic Boon
definition.description: You gain an Epic Boon feat or another feat of your choice for which you qualify.

definition.name: Words of Creation
definition.description: You have mastered two of the Words of Creation: the words of life and death. You therefore always have the Power Word Heal and Power Word Kill spells prepared. When you cast either spell, you can target a second creature with it if that creature is within 10 feet of the first target.
definition.snippet: You always have Power Word Heal and Power Word Kill prepared, and when you cast either spell, you can target a second creature if its within 10 ft. of the first target.

definition.name: Bardic Inspiration
definition.description:
You can supernaturally inspire others through words, music, or dance. This inspiration is represented by your Bardic Inspiration die, which is a d6.

Using Bardic Inspiration. As a Bonus Action, you can inspire another creature within 60 feet of yourself who can see or hear you. That creature gains one of your Bardic Inspiration dice. A creature can have only one Bardic Inspiration die at a time.

Once within the next hour when the creature fails a D20 Test, the creature can roll the Bardic Inspiration die and add the number rolled to the d20, potentially turning the failure into a success. A Bardic Inspiration die is expended when it’s rolled.

Number of Uses. You can confer a Bardic Inspiration die a number of times equal to your Charisma modifier (minimum of once), and you regain all expended uses when you finish a Long Rest.

At Higher Levels. Your Bardic Inspiration die changes when you reach certain Bard levels, as shown in the Bardic Die column of the Bard Features table. The die becomes a d8 at level 5, a d10 at level 10, and a d12 at level 15.
definition.snippet:
As a Bonus Action, you can inspire another creature within 60 ft. that can see or hear you. That creature gains one of your Bardic Inspiration dice ({{scalevalue}}). Once within the next hour, when the creature fails a D20 Test, the creature can roll the Bardic Inspiration die and add the number rolled to the total, potentially turning the failure into a success.

You can confer your Bardic Inspiration die {{modifier:cha@min:1#unsigned}} times per Short or Long Rest.

definition.name: 9: Expertise
definition.description: You gain Expertise in two more of your skill proficiencies of your choice.
definition.snippet: You gain Expertise in another two skill proficiencies of your choice.

definition.name: Charlatan Ability Score Improvements
definition.description: The Charlatan Background allows you to choose between Dexterity, Constitution, and Charisma. Increase one of these scores by 2 and another one by 1, or increase all three by 1. None of these increases can raise a score above 20.

definition.name: Skilled
definition.description:
Origin Feat

You gain proficiency in any combination of three skills or tools of your choice.

Repeatable. You can take this feat more than once.
definition.snippet: You gain proficiency in any combination of three skills or tools of your choice. Repeatable. You can take this feat more than once.

definition.name: Increase two scores (+2 / +1)
definition.description: Increase one of these scores by 2 and a different score by 1.

feat.label: Choose +2 to Dexterity, Constitution, or Charisma

class.name: Bardic Inspiration
class.description:
You can supernaturally inspire others through words, music, or dance. This inspiration is represented by your Bardic Inspiration die, which is a d6.

Using Bardic Inspiration. As a Bonus Action, you can inspire another creature within 60 feet of yourself who can see or hear you. That creature gains one of your Bardic Inspiration dice. A creature can have only one Bardic Inspiration die at a time.

Once within the next hour when the creature fails a [rules]D20 Test[/rules], the creature can roll the Bardic Inspiration die and add the number rolled to the d20, potentially turning the failure into a success. A Bardic Inspiration die is expended when it’s rolled.

Number of Uses. You can confer a Bardic Inspiration die a number of times equal to your Charisma modifier (minimum of once), and you regain all expended uses when you finish a Long Rest.

At Higher Levels. Your Bardic Inspiration die changes when you reach certain Bard levels, as shown in the Bardic Die column of the Bard Features table. The die becomes a d8 at level 5, a d10 at level 10, and a d12 at level 15.
class.snippet:
As a Bonus Action, you can inspire another creature within 60 ft. that can see or hear you. That creature gains one of your Bardic Inspiration dice ({{scalevalue}}). Once within the next hour, when the creature fails a D20 Test, the creature can roll the Bardic Inspiration die and add the number rolled to the total, potentially turning the failure into a success.

You can confer your Bardic Inspiration die {{modifier:cha@min:1#unsigned}} times per Long Rest.

race.restriction: to avoid or end the Frightened condition

definition.name: Starry Wisp
definition.description:
You launch a mote of light at one creature or object within range. Make a ranged spell attack against the target. On a hit, the target takes 1d8 Radiant damage, and until the end of your next turn, it emits Dim Light in a 10-foot radius and can’t benefit from the Invisible condition.

Cantrip Upgrade. The damage increases by 1d8 when you reach levels 5 (2d8), 11 (3d8), and 17 (4d8).

definition.name: Command
definition.description:
You speak a one-word command to a creature you can see within range. The target must succeed on a Wisdom saving throw or follow the command on its next turn. Choose the command from these options:

Approach. The target moves toward you by the shortest and most direct route, ending its turn if it moves within 5 feet of you.

Drop. The target drops whatever it is holding and then ends its turn.

Flee. The target spends its turn moving away from you by the fastest available means.

Grovel. The target has the Prone condition and then ends its turn.

Halt. On its turn, the target doesn’t move and takes no action or Bonus Action.

Using a Higher-Level Spell Slot. You can affect one additional creature for each spell slot level above 1.

definition.name: Cure Wounds
definition.description:
A creature you touch regains a number of Hit Points equal to 2d8 plus your spellcasting ability modifier.

Using a Higher-Level Spell Slot. The healing increases by 2d8 for each spell slot level above 1.

definition.name: Silvery Barbs
definition.description:
You magically distract the triggering creature and turn its momentary uncertainty into encouragement for another creature. The triggering creature must reroll the d20 and use the lower roll.

You can then choose a different creature you can see within range (you can choose yourself). The chosen creature has advantage on the next attack roll, ability check, or saving throw it makes within 1 minute. A creature can be empowered by only one use of this spell at a time.
definition.castingTimeDescription: which you take when a creature you can see within 60 feet of yourself succeeds on an attack roll, an ability check, or a saving throw

definition.name: Tasha's Hideous Laughter
definition.description:
One creature of your choice that you can see within range makes a Wisdom saving throw. On a failed save, it has the Prone and Incapacitated conditions for the duration. During that time, it laughs uncontrollably if it’s capable of laughter, and it can’t end the Prone condition on itself.

At the end of each of its turns and each time it takes damage, it makes another Wisdom saving throw. The target has Advantage on the save if the save is triggered by damage. On a successful save, the spell ends.

Using a Higher-Level Spell Slot. You can target one additional creature for each spell slot level about 1.

higherLevelDefinitions.details: You can target one additional creature for each spell slot level about 1.

definition.name: Vicious Mockery
definition.description:
You unleash a string of insults laced with subtle enchantments at one creature you can see or hear within range. The target must succeed on a Wisdom saving throw or take 1d6 Psychic damage and have Disadvantage on the next attack roll it makes before the end of its next turn.

Cantrip Upgrade. The damage increases by 1d6 when you reach levels 5 (2d6), 11 (3d6), and 17 (4d6).

modifiers.restriction: On target's next attack roll it makes before the end of its next turn
